captions.text:
(gunshot)
- Oh!
(slow James Bond themed music)
- I don't like guns at all.

- I don't have a negative
opinion about guns,
I do have negative opinions about people.

- I've been invited to a gun
range before with friends,
and I've said no, and I've just
sat in the car outside of the gun range
while they shot guns.

- I'm an Eagle Scout, I
was raised in the South,
I've shot a lot of guns.
.22 rifle, 10-gauge shotgun,
12-gauge shotgun, Desert Eagle,

and another type of handgun
that I don't remember.

- Who are you?
- It was my bachelor party.
- What?
- I shot an arrow once.

- I question why as a society

- It's like a James Bond thing,

and he's a cool, sexy guy,
and I'm a cool, sexy guy.
- They keep talking about James Bond.

- These are military grade weapons,

To kill a lot of people

We should be able to go to a gun range

- I'm going to go into this fresh,

Because maybe there is something

- If I get to wear a tuxedo

(fast typing)
- You could die here.

Only thing that you've

- Guy's I'm going to sh--
(gunshot)

- Alright, here goes nothing.
(gunshot)
- Oh, Jesus Christ!

- Assault rifles are actually

There's hardly any kick
because it goes so fast.

- Woo!
(gunshot)
- It's easy to forget why you're there,

that the purpose of these
guns is to kill people,
and each time you're pulling the trigger,
that's another life you could be taking.
- I'm Keith! How you doing?
- It gives you this real adrenaline
that took me hours to come down from.
- I think my body went on a high--
- [Voiceover] Yeah.

- [Voiceover] and I just
completely turned into this
very primitive, basic creature.

- [Voiceover] When you just
repeat shoot like that,

- [Voiceover] Me taking the safety off,

could've killed someone.
- Oh!
- Can I just get a hug?
Can I just get a hug real quick?
(fast typing)

- Does my cheekbone really have

- No, not too close.

- No, Lean your body forward.

- Okay.
- Okay.

(gunshot)
- Oh, mother of God!
This (beep) became like an adult toy.
Guns are not toys.

- Oh, every time it's
punching me in the arm.

Now that I've done it, I
get it, it's exhilarating.
- Oh, I feel that power!
It's like I'm turning into an animal.

I'm going to try and shoot
this guy in the nuts.
Who does that?
- Woo!
- I killed him!
How many times am I shooting this?

All I could think of

"Aw man, I hope I'm out of bullets."
(fast typing)

- Probably the biggest
- Damn
revolver that's commercially made.

- It's like playing a
round of golf with weapons.
- Exactly.

- If you feel the recoil
is too much for you,
let it go over your head.

Do not fight it, because
it will come back.

- Yeah, don't do that.
- Wow, it is heavy.

- Who do you think will be the

(laughing)

(gunshot)

(gunshot)
- Ahhhhh!

(gunshot)
- Ah!

(gunshot)
(Jeers)

I've not done it so many
times because I was afraid,

but I faced my fear, and
I think it's totally fine
to shoot any kind of gun in a gun range,
because that's the place you go.
You play golf on a golf course,
you shoot guns in a gun range.

- The first thing I said
when I held the gun was,

was I turned and then I

And all I can think of is I'm desperately

It doesn't necessarily

- For the record, for me personally,

eating pizza is still
more of a genuine thrill
than shooting a gun.
- Yeah, this is pretty good.
And, it's quite a kick.

comments.author: Jensen Payne

comments.text:
I don't see any real problem with having guns for entertainment or hunting 
(when practiced safely and appropriately of course), and I don't 
necessarily have a problem with the average person being able to own a gun 
(don't think it's necessary, but not a "bad" thing), however I do have a 
problem with the American "way" of gun ownership.

There are plenty other countries with access to guns with not nearly as 
many horrible incidents in the states. It's all about the mentality of the 
owner. I won't say all Americans, as one can't account for all based on the 
actions of many, but a lot USA culture revolves around guns (pun intended) 
in many aspects, especially their ever-known "freedom". It's this mentality 
that leads people to believe it's okay to shoot at teenagers on their lawn 
(witnessed this on a few different occasions in both the south and north 
and have heard about it plenty more) or just about anyone, many times 
justifying it by saying that "they have/had a gun (as well)" or "I have a 
right to protect yourself/property" (which you do, but certainly not by 
killing people). Living in a country knowing that not everyone I pass on 
the street is likely packing heat is a comforting thought, I can't imagine 
feeling safe in a place where I felt it necessary to have a gun. Not to 
mention if you have a gun for self defense - no matter your justification 
in my mind - you are willing the accept the potential of intentionally 
killing someone. And that's something I personally could never do.

So if anyone who carries a gun around for self defense has read this far, 
can you please explain to your friendly Canadian neighbour why you think it 
okay to take such drastic measures? Hopefully I haven't offended you; I'm 
not calling American culture stupid or anything of the like, I just cannot 
understand this mentality and how this could ever be seen as "normal/to be 
expected". So if you disagree please explain, thanks!﻿

comments.author: CletusandWalter

comments.text:
I have quite a few problems with this video. For starters, there is no such 
thing as an accidental shooting (not that they made mention of it), but 
there is negligent shootings which account for all "accidental" shootings. 
Such as what happened in this video when someone who had nearly no firearm 
experienced was handed a loaded firearm and it "went off" before he was 
"ready". 
This isn't his fault, but the fault of the safety guard or aka Range Guard. 
These guys should have underwent a 3 hour training class before touching 
these firearms if they have zero firearm knowledge or have never fired a 
gun. 

I also take issue with the thought of guns are meant to kill, and only do 
so. 
I say this as an eight tour former EOD Tech who served in both Operation 
Iraqi Freedom and Operation Enduring Freedom. 
Firearms are not made to kill, they're made to send a bullet [projectile of 
a cartridge] down towards what it [the firearm] is being aimed at. Nothing 
more, nothing less. 
To say the gun is intending to do anything is just not true. If you set up 
a piece of string in front of a doorway, you can't say that it was the 
strings intentions to be there. Nor that the string is automatically going 
to trip someone who may walk by. That is determined by the person who sets 
up the string. 

That being said, as a Combat vet, a gun owner and a range owner, I take 
extreme offense to the employee/[possible] owner who said " you can die 
here today". While thats true, they could die if they mishandle the 
firearm. 
You NEVER say something like that, that comment was made literally to haze 
or scare them. 
If I walked into a range and was told that I would demand to see their FFL 
and I would call the ATF. 
But hey, that's me. 

[Ret.] U.S. Navy ﻿
comments.author: GermKing566

comments.text:
another note. I also take HUGE issue with the range letting them fire a S&W 
.500 without proper knowledge of firearms. 

A lady last year killed herself when the gun came back around and hit her 
in the head putting her in a coma. 

Guns arent toys, you can love them, cherish them and depending where you 
are, brand them and show them off. 
But in no way should a firearm be handled by someone who cannot handle it. 

As a former EOD Tech, I worked along side SEALs, Berets, CSO's, and general 
grunts. 
Very few of them, even the most experienced, have no intentions on picking 
up a .500, little less shooting it. 

Shooting Firearms is like drinking. Know your limits people...

comments.text:
You may think that shooting a gun may not make you manly. A gun is a tool 
and a deadly tool for that matter. In order to know how to handle it and 
control such a thing should take the maturity of a man. These employees of 
Buzzfeed treat these tools as if they are simply toys. They do not portray 
a level of adulthood that should show fans how guns should be handled. Do 
not take these employees as a figure of expert knowledge of how to handle a 
rifle/shotgun/handgun or even a kitchen knife. Guns were made to hunt for 
food. In certain parts of the world they are still manufactured for that 
purpose. Guns are not made for the sole desire to kill. There is a sport of 
hand and eye coordination that is even put on display in the Olympics. The 
Biathlon. You gentlemen have done a superb job of lowering your character 
and whatever you may have hoped to portray in this vain attempt to show 
people how you view guns in general.﻿

guns aren't part of American culture, they're part of this perceived

and they give this country a bad image. I grew up in the north east and 
currently live in California, and I have never EVER had friends who owned 
or ever shot a gun. I'd just like to point out that even in much of 
America, a good number of us see gun culture as particularly uncivilized, 
unnecessary, and kind of a "hick" thing.

And additionally, hunting is disgusting. Killing harmless animals for 
pleasure and sport is absolutely disgusting.﻿

guns from law abiding people. Examples: Adolf Hilter, Mao Tze Tung, Josef 
Stalin, Pol Pot, Idi Amin, etc.﻿
